Lp spaces

Let f∈Lloc1(Rd)f \in L^1_{\mathrm{loc}}\p{\R^d}f∈Lloc1​(Rd) be such that for some 0<p<10 < p < 10<p<1, we have

∣∫f(x)g(x) dx∣≤(∫∣g(x)∣p dx)1/p,\abs{\int f\p{x} g\p{x} \,\diff{x}} \leq \p{\int \abs{g\p{x}}^p \,\diff{x}}^{1/p},∣∣​∫f(x)g(x)dx∣∣​≤(∫∣g(x)∣pdx)1/p,

for all g∈C0(Rd)g \in C_0\p{\R^d}g∈C0​(Rd). Show that f(x)=0f\p{x} = 0f(x)=0 a.e. Here C0(Rd)C_0\p{\R^d}C0​(Rd) is the space of continuous functions with compact support on Rd\R^dRd.
Solution.

Let KKK be a compact set and ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0. Since KKK is bounded, there exists R>0R > 0R>0 such that K⊆B(0,R)K \subseteq B\p{0, R}K⊆B(0,R). Since f∈L1(B(0,R))f \in L^1\p{B\p{0, R}}f∈L1(B(0,R)), the map E↦∫B(0,R)∩E∣f(x)∣ dxE \mapsto \int_{B\p{0, R} \cap E} \abs{f\p{x}} \,\diff{x}E↦∫B(0,R)∩E​∣f(x)∣dx defines a measure absolutely continuous with respect to the Lebesgue measure. Hence, there exists δ>0\delta > 0δ>0 such that if m(E)<δm\p{E} < \deltam(E)<δ, then

∫B(0,R)∩E∣f(x)∣ dx<ε.\int_{B\p{0, R} \cap E} \abs{f\p{x}} \,\diff{x} < \epsilon.∫B(0,R)∩E​∣f(x)∣dx<ε.

By regularity of the Lebesgue measure, there exists an open set K⊆U⊆B(0,R)K \subseteq U \subseteq B\p{0, R}K⊆U⊆B(0,R) such that m(U∖K)<δm\p{U \setminus K} < \deltam(U∖K)<δ, and so ∫U∖K∣f(x)∣ dx<ε\int_{U \setminus K} \abs{f\p{x}} \,\diff{x} < \epsilon∫U∖K​∣f(x)∣dx<ε. Shrinking δ\deltaδ further, we may assume that δ<ε\delta < \epsilonδ<ε. Hence,

∣∫Kf(x) dx∣=∣∫Kf(x)g(x) dx∣=∣∫Uf(x)g(x) dx−∫U∖Kf(x)g(x) dx∣≤∣∫Uf(x)g(x) dx∣+∫U∖K∣f(x)∣ dx≤(∫∣g(x)∣p dx)1/p+ε≤m(U)1/p+ε≤(m(K)+δ)1/p+ε≤(m(K)+ε)1/p+ε.\begin{aligned} \abs{\int_K f\p{x} \,\diff{x}} &= \abs{\int_K f\p{x}g\p{x} \,\diff{x}} \\ &= \abs{\int_U f\p{x}g\p{x} \,\diff{x} - \int_{U \setminus K} f\p{x}g\p{x} \,\diff{x}} \\ &\leq \abs{\int_U f\p{x}g\p{x} \,\diff{x}} + \int_{U \setminus K} \abs{f\p{x}} \,\diff{x} \\ &\leq \p{\int \abs{g\p{x}}^p \,\diff{x}}^{1/p} + \epsilon \\ &\leq m\p{U}^{1/p} + \epsilon \\ &\leq \p{m\p{K} + \delta}^{1/p} + \epsilon \\ &\leq \p{m\p{K} + \epsilon}^{1/p} + \epsilon. \end{aligned}∣∣​∫K​f(x)dx∣∣​​=∣∣​∫K​f(x)g(x)dx∣∣​=∣∣​∫U​f(x)g(x)dx−∫U∖K​f(x)g(x)dx∣∣​≤∣∣​∫U​f(x)g(x)dx∣∣​+∫U∖K​∣f(x)∣dx≤(∫∣g(x)∣pdx)1/p+ε≤m(U)1/p+ε≤(m(K)+δ)1/p+ε≤(m(K)+ε)1/p+ε.​

Sending ε→0\epsilon \to 0ε→0, we see that the given inequality also works when ggg is the characteristic equation on a compact set. We will now emphasize the fact that LpL^pLp does not satisfy the triangle inequality for 0<p<10 < p < 10<p<1: let QQQ be a cube with side length LLL, and for each N∈NN \in \NN∈N, decompose QQQ into almost disjoint cubes QnQ_nQn​ with side lengths LN\frac{L}{N}NL​. Then

∣∫f(x)χQ(x) dx∣≤∑n=1Nd∣∫f(x)χQn dx∣≤∑n=1Ndm(Qn)1/p=∑n=1NdLdNd/p=LdNd(1p−1)→N→∞0,\begin{aligned} \abs{\int f\p{x} \chi_Q\p{x} \,\diff{x}} \leq \sum_{n=1}^{N^d} \abs{\int f\p{x} \chi_{Q_n} \,\diff{x}} &\leq \sum_{n=1}^{N^d} m\p{Q_n}^{1/p} \\ &= \sum_{n=1}^{N^d} \frac{L^d}{N^{d/p}} \\ &= \frac{L^d}{N^{d\p{\frac{1}{p}-1}}} \xrightarrow{N\to\infty} 0, \end{aligned}∣∣​∫f(x)χQ​(x)dx∣∣​≤n=1∑Nd​∣∣​∫f(x)χQn​​dx∣∣​​≤n=1∑Nd​m(Qn​)1/p=n=1∑Nd​Nd/pLd​=Nd(p1​−1)Ld​N→∞​0,​

since 1p−1>0\frac{1}{p} - 1 > 0p1​−1>0. Indeed, since 0<p<10 < p < 10<p<1, the right-hand side shrinks instead of growing as N→∞N \to \inftyN→∞. Thus, we have shown that ∫Qf(x) dx=0\int_Q f\p{x} \,\diff{x} = 0∫Q​f(x)dx=0 for any cube. Hence, by the Lebesgue differentiation theorem, we see that f(x)=0f\p{x} = 0f(x)=0 almost everywhere.
